captions.text: Good morning John, and happy Pizzamas.

As I think you expected, people have been
enjoying your green-screen time. They're calling

it John Greenscreened; it's a thing, it's
beautiful. But I want to skip back another

video, to the almost incalculably distant
Friday video that I did, in which I used the

word "dipthong". Which, unfortunately, does
not exist. The word I was going for was diphthong,
which is also really great.

I have pronounced and spelled diphthong wrong
for at least a decade. I am not embarrassed

about my misunderstanding with the diphthong
word, and I want to know why!

In college, I did an oral presentation on
Leon Battista Alberti, who was a mathematician,

architect, and artist of the Renaissance.
Super cool dude, if you ever want to learn

about him. He designed a great number of the
fronts of buildings in Florence. Those fronts

of buildings are called that word (façade),
which I said, for the entire presentation,

"fah-caid". Like, 26 times, I said "fah-caid",
and I knew something wasn't going well, but

I just powered through, you know, and then
found out later, from a friend, "fuh-SAHD".
Anhhhhhhh . . .

So I mispronounced Diphthong in front of 200,000
people - didn't bother me. "Fah-caid", in

front of twenty people, left a permanent scar.
Like, I still have a hard time telling that

story. What is the difference between those
two things? I think it's mostly confidence.

Like, being confident when you're wrong is
one of the most amazing things you can be.

It's wonderful... if you can pull it off,
which is impossible.

I don't mean confidence in believing a thing
that is wrong and continuing to believe a

thing despite knowing that it's wrong, which
some people are really into. I mean, finding

out you're wrong, knowing you're wrong, and
being confident in your understanding of your

own wrongness. When you see someone be super-wrong
and be like, "Eh, whatever, yeah, I was wrong.

Yeah! Thanks for letting me know!" you're
like "That person is cool. They're cool. How
do I get that?"

Feeling fine about being wrong is the logical
way to feel, because, as I have pointed out

in previous videos, I am a towering mountain
of ignorance, and all simplicity is a lie.

Even when you're right, you're a little bit
wrong!

Getting to a place where I feel comfortable
enough with myself to have internalized that

truth, even a little bit, has been a lifelong
process. And really, it only works when I'm

in places and with people who I trust and
know and understand and feel good about and

feel confident around, which is the case here
- the Vlogbrothers channel and nerdfighteria.

Embarrassment really isn't about being wrong,
it's about feeling wrong, and it is hard for

me to feel wrong here, because you guys are
nice.

Sometimes the most embarrassing part of the
embarrassment is the embarrassment itself!

That's weird! In the comments on my Friday
video, I owned up, and I said that I mispronounced

"dipthong," just like John recently mispronounced
"hectacre," and I asked people to tell me
their hectacre moments.

And I read through them, just before I made
this video, and it was wonderful. There's

like 300 replies and they're all hilarious
and wince-inducing. But several of them were

also façade, which made me feel better about
myself, and I think in general, that thread

was cathartic for all the people who participated
in it.

Being wrong is part of what it is to be a
person. And you have to work on how to be

wrong without feeling wrong. I think that
thread was a good start. So I'm going to ask

all of you: if you got a little time, tell
us an embarrassing thing that has happened

to you. We can read it and feel better about
ourselves, knowing that everyone does dumb
things!

But I think owning it is the number one thing
you can do, and I think the other thing you

can do is let people know who are admitting
to their embarrassing things that have happened

to them, that they're awesome, and that that's
hilarious, and not to worry about it.

That's hopefully what's going on in the comments;
John, I'll see you tomorrow.

Hi, endscreen! This is sad - only three days
left of Pizzamas, but the Project for Awesome

is coming up, so there are reasons to celebrate
the future. Because of Paper Towns shoot dates,

we're actually moving the Project for Awesome
up this year, it's going to be the 12th and

13th of December. So mark your calendars and
start planning your videos.

title: How to Never Feel Embarrassed Again

comments.text:
This does not really have much to do with the video, just something I 
wanted to say.
When I subscribed the Vlogbrothers' channel I was thinking "Hey, these guys 
make some interesting videos." but did not expect much more.
Only now I am beginning to realize of what I have become a part, meaning 
Nerdfighteria. As someone who normally avoids the comment section I am 
positively surprised about how warm and welcoming an environment the 
comments under every single one of John's and Hank's are. 
Keep it up, nerdfighters, you are awesome.﻿
comments.author: Remsma KH

comments.text:
And suddenly my head starts to sing: We see ourselves in the cracks in his 
facade...﻿
comments.author: Lue ssi

comments.text:
you just called the youtube comment box nice. I think you need to read 
other peoples youtube comment boxes.﻿
comments.author: DarkKnightofHeaven

comments.text:
Ok, my embarrassing story:

So my girlfriend and I met as dance majors and then she went on to withdraw 
from the program due to injury, but she still was on the roster for pretty 
much all of my classes. So naturally I had to explain why she was not 
there. During attendance on the first day of one of my classes, I explained 
the story, to which this exchange happened:

Teacher: You good friends with her?
Me: Uh....I'm dating her....
Teacher: **long pause** That's all I need to know.....
Class:**laughs**


UGHHHHHHHHHHHHHHANDIWASTRYINGTOAVOIDAWKWARDNESSGAAAAAAH

So....yeah....oddly enough the teacher got a kick out of it and though it 
was funny. I don't know how....﻿
comments.author: lucastark

comments.text:
I showed up about an hour and thirty minutes early to my first day of my 
psychology class a few years ago. I was the first student to arrive, so I 
took a seat in the front row of the classroom. I had been waiting at least 
45 minutes for someone to show up but still nobody had come in yet. It was 
just me sitting in there by myself. So to pass the time, I figured I would 
listen to some music. I was listening to the song Justin Timberlake made 
for SNL called "Dick in a Box", and because I had been waiting in there by 
myself for so long, I kept replaying the song. By the third time that I 
replayed the song, I had actually begun to sing along a little bit. 
Normally when I sing a song, I sing in a silly voice so it doesn't look 
like I take myself too seriously. But because I actually like the song and 
find it catchy, I was singing along quite passionately. I was using some 
really good headphones that day too, so I couldn't hear anything but the 
song. Due to the fact that I was sitting in the very front of the room and 
the entrance to the class was in the very back of the room, I had failed to 
notice that the room was steadily filling up with students behind me while 
I was passionately singing along to a song about presenting my genitals in 
a box. It was only until someone sat in the desk next to me that I had 
realized the error of my ways. After my classmate sat next to me, I 
immediately panicked. I knew she had to have heard my loud singing. But she 
said nothing. Then I turned around to find a room completely full of my new 
classmates behind me. Some of them were laughing, some of them stared in 
confusion and slight disbelief. Needless to say, I had made the most 
priceless first impression ever.﻿
comments.author: 90s kid

comments.text:
Err... Left my pillow's *ahem* "clothing" on.
My girlfriend saw them and well, let's just say that even now, after 3 
years, I still get embarrassed when I see her, or them! XD﻿
comments.author: Brandon McGrath (Dasher The Viral)

comments.text:
Peculiar. I read fast and always read it as pecular. therefore I always say 
it that way and nobody knows what I'm talking about. It's a very pecular 
situation.﻿
comments.author: Izabella Deeg

comments.text:
For a really long time I was convinced the capital of Finland was called 
Helinski. I just always read it that way without paying too much attention 
to the exact order of letters I guess. Until one day whan I was about 16 or 
17 I think I got into a very heated discussion over it with a classmate. I 
am afraid I even went as far as mocking him for calling it Helsinki which 
just sounded wrong to me. It wasn't until he showed me his atlas and I 
learned that I had been wrong all along...﻿
comments.author: mithwenarataur

comments.text:
When I was in the 5th Grade I tried to convince everyone that I could 
communicate to the Yeti, so I would go out on the play ground and yell, 
"YETI YETI YETI YETI" on top of the play structure and then tell everyone 
if they didn't believe in the yeti, he'd come to kill them, but I'd be safe 
because I knew how to talk to him....
I watched too much History Channel and received plenty of weird looks to 
last my lifetime﻿
comments.author: Malak Ghazal

comments.text:
I pronounced "misled" incorrectly for my entire life. Instead of 
"miss-LED", I would say "MYE-zold." I thought it was connected with being 
an old miser -- a miser is one who misles! Anyway, I said it out loud in a 
graduate course and everyone just paused, trying to understand what they 
just heard. A weird sinkhole opened up in my stomach as I realized what 
happened. But dang it if I still can't see "misled" without pronouncing it 
wrong in my head.﻿
comments.author: Carolyn Bishoff

comments.text:
I like to think that I am quite famous in the community where I live. I 
participate in a number of community events, perform on stage regularly and 
people seem to remember me due to my personality and general behaviour. So, 
it sometimes happens that people who I do not instantly recognize greet me 
on the streets, sometimes even in my native language - Spanish. So. Having 
said that... A few months ago, I was walking by a dog park and I heard 
someone calling me loudly: "Hola!" I turned around and saw this lady waving 
at me. I returned her greeting: "¡Hola, hola! ¿Qué tal?", but didn't stop 
and kept on walking. I was in a hurry, after all. But then, as I was 
walking away, I heard the same voice shouting again, but this time I heard 
more clearly. She said "Lola!". She was calling her dog! Isn't that 
embarrasing!?﻿
comments.author: ALFREDO FRANCO

comments.text:
Weeelll i was at work and i had a battery a piece of paper and a screw 
driver in my pocket and long story short set my shirt on fire. xp now i 
didnt get hurt buuut my shirt was ruined and i had to finish work with a 
giant hole in in the chest of it and everyone asking me ".... davey.... 
what happened to ur shirt..."﻿

comments.text: Guys, are you twins? O.o﻿

comments.author: Julian Gypens

comments.text:
I'm a little late to this party but, que sera sera. 
So I went to a clothing trade thingy with my best friend and the guy I 
liked. Well nobody had given us the heads up that there was a pool there. 
So we had to wear our clothes into the pool, then change into some that we 
got at the trade. Of course there were no undergarments there at the trade, 
so I had to wear the soaked ones from the pool on the way home. Once we got 
home my mom goes, we have to take (We'll call him A) A home, so you girls 
go get changed into some fresh underwear so you don't get rashes anywhere 
important. I LITERALLY STOPPED DEAD IN MY TRACKS AND LOOKED AT A AND HE WAS 
LAUGHING REALLY AWKWARDLY. I just wanted to die. After typing this out, I 
realize that this isn't the most embarrassing story ever, but I still 
cringe at the thought of it.﻿
comments.author: faithisboring

comments.text:
I once was told that my friend was pregnant and she was 16 at the time. I 
started to freak out because she was not the type of person to do something 
like that. Was she raped did some one take advantage of her? I didn't know. 
Everyone then told me she was not pregnant, and to stop hyperventilating. 
Not awkward for so much as just really stressful. Never play a joke like 
that on anyone!﻿
comments.author: Wyatt Kidd

comments.text:
WAIT IT'S NOT DIPTHONG?
I was definitely, definitely taught that it was dipthong in my English 
classes.
I have a Bachelor's degree in English!!
(Standby while I look this up...)

...It's 100% diphthong. BUT 'dip-thong is an alternate pronunciation.﻿

My friend walked up to me and was like, "Hey, you're one of my really good 
friends." And I replied with, "I know." What I meant to say was, "Thanks! 
You're one of my good friends also." , but I freaking said, " I know" 
......﻿
comments.author: .__BRYLAY__

comments.text:
In second grade, my teacher asked me to spell peanuts. So I did. 
P-E-A-N-U-S. She gave me the best "What the f***" look I've ever seen and 
two boys started giggling. I had no idea what I'd done until 6th grade. It 
forever haunts me. ﻿
comments.author: Potato Girl

comments.text:
Hank, please don't judge. So umm...when I was eight my momma and my step 
dad were getting married and at the rehearsal dinner I was supposed to make 
a little statement about my new dad. Well see, as I was walking up, I 
tripped over a 'too long' table cloth and brought down everything. Plates 
cups and flowers, I was attacked by forks! It was scarring. But of course I 
wouldn't ruin my mom's wedding so I just stood up, pulled the broccoli out 
of my hair, took the microphone, and said, "Boy! Do I know how to make and 
entrance or what?!" And I swear to this very day, I still have table cloth 
trust issues.... 


I can feel your judging through the computer... Stop it! It was an 
accident.... I'm a really clumsy person okay, I mean I know the floor on a 
first name basis at this point. Stop judging me!﻿
comments.author: Book Junkie

comments.text: lol﻿
comments.author: John Flowers

comments.text:
The difference between those 2 stories is based on how many people also 
mispronounce that word. Most people say dipthong instead of diphthong but 
most people know facade instead of fakade ﻿
comments.author: Patrick Boyd

comments.text:
i thought the name Deborah was pronounce De-a-bor at first glace. My boss 
laughed at me..﻿
comments.author: cheesebean4040

comments.text: Until I was ten, I pronounced "relieved" as RE-VAY-ALD.﻿
comments.author: Fiona Caitlin

comments.text:
Embarrasment is something we create ourselves..... Embarrassment stops us 
from doing things which we otherwise would have done if we were not 
embarrassed. It stops us from being innocent and seeing the world from a 
child's perspective. For many of us it is the very cause that stops us from 
following our dreams. To make myself free from embarrasment i do things 
which might make me embarrassed on a daily basis so as to get accquinted to 
the feeling so that it never becomes a hurdle for me. Those things 
include-running in the footpath when everyone else is walking, picking 
garbages from the street itself, doing things which others might think to 
be awkward.﻿
comments.author: Ayan Shah

comments.text:
One day I went to the principal's office, stood up on his desk and pulled 
my pants down, I think I was 6 and I used to watch Beavis & Butt-head... 
the moral of the story is: supervise the actions of your kids at all costs 
(I didn't felt embarrassed but it was funny)﻿
comments.author: GTBehemoth

comments.text:
When I was little I thought a faeces was the same thing as a foetus.....
Science lessons didn't go that well for me.﻿
comments.author: Sophie Payne

comments.text:
We once went to a holiday resort where my Dad took a sailing course. He 
took this sailing course with an incredibly hairy man and nicknamed him the 
werewolf... later on that day he was sitting at a table with some of his 
freinds and said "watch out for the werewolf i wouldnt want to be near him 
on a full moon". What my dad didnt know was that the "werewolf" was behind 
him as he said this. He did a pretend growl in my dads ear and walked off. 
I swear he has never gone so red in his life.﻿
comments.author: Sophie Payne

comments.text:
I had worn a dress on an extremely windy day and while taking pictures of 
softball players for a school assignment, my dress kept lifting up and i'm 
pretty sure everyone saw my shorts under and my mother yelled at me because 
she said every man was watching me and basically objectifying me and saying 
that they react that way because I dress a certain way and my mother is 
extremely ignorant and i'm, honestly, flustered. I know the men were so 
fucking stupid and lacking a sex life to where they couldn't have enough 
human decency to understand the situation and not stare and make a big deal 
out of something which was a mistake. I hate the fact that i'm being 
shunned for something that was an accident but i'm also extremely 
embarrassed because some people, and staff, from my school were there and I 
don't know what to do. Any help? ﻿
comments.author: anamyerss

comments.text:
So I have four.

A couple of years ago, I was in Social Studies class and we were doing a 
trivia game. (Nota Bene, my teacher's dog just died and his name was 
Jackson). The question was, "Who directed the Lord of The Rings trilogy?" 
When he revealed that the answer was Peter Jackson, he asked, "Do you know 
who that reminds me of?" And I swear I didn't mean to be funny, but I said 
"Percy Jackson!" right as he mentioned his dead dog. I still feel horrible 
about it.

Every single YT comment I've made in the period of 2010 to 2012. Oh god.

A couple of years ago, my friend and I were talking to this older kid, and 
he asked us a question like, "Did you know that A is B miles away from C?" 
And I'm a sarcastic kid, so I said, "Oh totally. It's common knowledge to 
know that."Well, I guess I didn't make my sarcasm clear enough because he 
thought I was serious and said, "I was lying." He probably still thinks I'm 
an idiot.

So I've gotten good at not being embarrassed when I drop my stick or mallet 
in band class and it makes a loud noise, but one time I dropped my 
drumstick in a performance at a coffee shop. I reached for an extra one 
from the drumstick holder on the high hat stand, but that fell off and the 
sticks rolled off the stage. I had to stop playing completely in order to 
get the previous drumstick that I dropped. It was awful.﻿
comments.author: Zach Dragg

comments.text:
I had a fight with this lass at school a chunk of hair came out and some of 
hers but mostly mine cod I have fin hair and every one started laughthing 
at me but at least I won lol but today I have acting school and I don't 
want them seeing my hair like this I am just starting this new acting 
school and I am nevous luckily if I put it in a bun nobody will see it xxx 
now every one is arguing x﻿
comments.author: tottyanne2010

comments.text:
When I was 11 I spelled "Hello" "Hallow"

It's still hard telling people this...﻿
comments.author: Bgirl

comments.text:
In 6th grade a had this alarm backpack, so if anyone tried to grab me or 
something I just pull the key out and it goes off. Well I went to a 
different classroom for a little bit, and left my backpack in my other 
class. So anyways, someone saw it, and got curious as to what it is. So 
they pulled it making it go off. No body knew what was happening, so they 
thought it was a bomb. They started to evacuate the whole school. Just to 
find out later it was my backpack... I got sent up to the office and 
everything. The next week, we were talking get about favorite songs, and my 
teacher was like "I bet Kaelyn's favorite song is Pound the Alarm by Nicky 
Minaj" and everyone looked at me and everyone was laughing because by then 
the whole school knew it was my backpack. And in NY yearbook, he write 
something like "I'll never forget you Kaelyn, mainly because of you 
backpack." That was embarrassing...﻿
comments.author: Kae Girl

comments.text:
Embarrassing moments? When I realize that I don't want to listen to other 
people's opinions because they don't fit in with my biases, and I say mean 
things to them (or totally ignore them) because I think that they are wrong 
and I am right.﻿
comments.author: Skye ID

comments.text:
In the summer before my seventh grade year, I confused a complete stranger 
for an older kid who knew my brother whilst looking for said brother. He 
was confused when I kept asking "Where's Jake?", and I felt like a complete 
idiot.
Long story short, he's now one of my closest friends.﻿
comments.author: Liam Arduino

comments.text:
Well this one time my dad and I were at this sports bar in France, watching 
a game, we were sitting at our table and stuff, and some dude next to us, 
put up his hand in a gesture that I so greatly mistook for a high five... 
So there I was high-fiving this person I have never seen before for no 
reason whatsoever, of course, accompanied by this great look of confusion 
on his face. Turns out the guy was my dad's friend from university whom he 
hasn't seen in 30 years, and he was in fact waving hello to my dad, and NOT 
high-fiving me ... It's like all the odds conspired against me in that 
brief moment of utter embarrassment XD﻿
comments.author: Lea Saffiedine

comments.text:
It's probably already been said, but "DIP-thong" is also a valid 
pronunciation of diphthong. See 
http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/diphthong.﻿
comments.author: Matt Harden

comments.text:
I went to an Ed Sheeran concert about a month ago.  I got to the arena an 
hour before the doors were opened, and wasn't sure which door I should 
enter from. I saw a crowd of people and decided to go stand with them. I 
stood there in the cold freezing, trying to stay warm. When they finally 
opened the doors I was getting so excited. That lasted for about 20 minutes 
in which I had only moved 30cm closer to the door. Then I finally took my 
ticket out, and saw my seat number and realised I head been standing in 
front of the floor entrance. My entrance was from a different door. A door 
that for the hour and 20 minutes I had been waiting had no line.﻿
comments.author: kahurikuul

comments.text:
As long as we're sharing stories of embarrassing mispronunciations, in my 
Amazing Spider-Man review, I said contribution as contribu (i.e. 
contribute)-tion.﻿
comments.author: OptimusPhillip

comments.text:
I have a truly incredible number of these, but the most recent one was when 
I pronounced Descartes as "des-cart-ees" to a room full of my coworkers, 
while telling them that I had read Meditations already. (To be fair, I HAD. 
I just... hadn't ever.... talked about him. Out loud. Or learned how to 
pronounce French names.)

STILL CRINGING.﻿
comments.author: Dee Winterbottom

comments.text:
My stomach ALWAYS starts rumbling when I'm in class and everyone is quiet. 
And embarrasses me, because to people it might sound like farting. But I 
can't control the sounds my stomach makes. 

ANOTHER EMBARRASSING STORY:
The other day I was talking to two of my friends and said Clown instead of 
clone. But we were talking above each other so no one mentioned it. I'm 
sure they heard it. I realised my mistake right afterwards. But since no 
one mentioned it, correcting my mistake after pensively thinking about how 
horrible it was seemed even more awkward. ﻿
comments.author: L

comments.text:
I was once in my local walmart store and found a video game that I really 
wanted, so I turned to my mom and tugged on her sleeve, looking her dead in 
the eyes and saying, "Mama, we have to get this!" 

It was not my mom. It was another women with the same hair cut.

This stranger and I legitimately just stared at each other with pure 
awkwardness in the air until I just put the video game back on the shelf 
and walked away. 

I didn't get the video game.﻿
comments.author: Payton Romans

comments.text:
Once when I was in Kindergarten I had accidentally peed in my pants during 
class and when my teacher asked me if it was me I denied it and blamed it 
on a boy across from me until my teacher finally knew it was me and sent me 
to the nurses office to change. I still remember pointing to the boy in 
front of the whole class. Poor kid ﻿
comments.author: Samantha Rodriguez

comments.text:
I have just endured this: I was talking to this guy. Very cool. Very cute. 
And I mention kissing him as friends. (Euphemism) Sadly, I got his hopes 
high and he believed I was offering a kiss but alas, I wasn't, creating the 
most embarrassing moment in history due to his excitement that I crushed 
like a grape! ﻿
comments.author: Jasmine Isnotadalek

comments.text:
Back when I was in elementary school, I came home to tell my mom that I had 
learned a new word: opspiment.  No, she said, the word was obstinate.  But 
I would not budge; it was pronounced opspiment!  You could say I was 
obstinate that it was pronounced opspiment.﻿
comments.author: Cara Miles

comments.text:
I made once a presentation about coca-cola. And English is not my first 
language ( it's luxemburgish). 
And I forget the word side effects, so I said Nebenwirkungen (In a weird 
English accent) in the hope that no one would realize it.
They did.﻿
comments.author: Joanne Möller

comments.text:
I once was giving a presentation in front of about 20 people. I didn't take 
the paper up with me because it was only a paragraph and I thought I had 
memorized. In the middle of my presentation I forgot everything. I stood 
there for 1-2 minutes until I finally remembered. I never go up on stage 
without a script anymore. :)﻿
comments.author: Hadiyah Carriere

comments.text:
I got into car and started telling my dad about how whatever I was doing 
went (I forgot what it was that I was doing, all that I remember was the 
embarrassing part). Only to realize that it wasn't my dad. It was a white 
haired lady who was very confused and scared. I apologised and my sister, 
who realized it was not our dad's car before I did, seemed to think I am an 
absolute idiot. Her thinking was very justified.﻿
comments.author: Fay Sprader

comments.text: ...wait a minute...did he mispronounce "mispronounced" on purpose?﻿
comments.author: Liv M.

comments.text:
I did a really big presentation a year ago for world geography and I spent 
a ton of time on it. I was really prepared and in the end for a B on it. 
But when I finished presenting the teacher told me that the hoover dam was 
in Nevada and not in Ohio like I said. I knew it was in Nevada but even 
with all the research I said it was on Ohio!!! Oh well. I got a B :D﻿
comments.author: Johnathan Fisher

comments.text:
2:23 That gesture is a really good one. I don't know why, but I do have an 
artist's eye, and that gesture was really artistic.﻿

comments.text:
WHY DOES THE RED SQUIGGLY LINE STILL HAPPEN WHENEVER I TYPE THE WORD"VLOG" 
ITS 2015﻿

comments.text:
i discovered the vlog brothers through watching crash course in science 
class.....wow just wow........﻿
comments.author: Run To The Sky

comments.text:
McDonalds drive thru with my friend. He ordered a yogurt parfait and 
pronounced it par-fee-at. So embarrassing. ﻿
comments.author: Wolf Ram

comments.text:
I have entirely too many embarrassing moments to choose from. On the first 
day of middle school for me, I had PE and me and this other girl went to 
change and we didn't know why there wasn't anyone else changing, so we 
changed quickly and went into the gym, and we weren't supposed to change 
out until the second week of school. Also, I have a lot of friends who are 
very dirty minded, I'm not really that perverted, so I tend to say stuff 
that I take as normal but they take as innuendos and it's always so 
embarrassing when they start laughing and I'm like "what? Why are you 
laughing" and they're always like "that sounded so wrong" or start making 
dirty jokes about it and I'm just like "no I didn't mean it like that....". 
When they do that its like hell﻿
comments.author: Gianna

comments.text: Haha, I get this all the time.
comments.author: Fawkesgirl33

comments.text:
I've spent my whole life calling a lyre a 'l-EE-r' partly because I was 
taught by a British documentary narrator (damn you David! *shakes fist*) 
and partly because that is the way it is pronounced in another language 
('l-EE-ra'). I only recently found out that I'd been wrong while I was 
talking with one of my friends about a character we like, but I just can't 
break the habit!!! Screw it, it sounds nicer anyways.﻿
comments.author: Kitty Litter

comments.text:
Two years ago I was saying an essay about martial arts in front of my 
entire grade, which was about 125 people. I only agreed because I wanted to 
break out of my shy shell. Horrifyingly instead of bringing my essay like I 
thought I did not bring a rough draft or anything doable, but a random pile 
of information with no order. Some needed information was left out and 
others I didn't need. I remembered only little of my essay being the stage 
fright person I was. I was flipping through pages, stuttering, 
mispronouncing the simplest words, spitting out random facts or just 
pausing when I couldn't find or remember the info I needed to. It was a 
nightmare. When I asked, my friends said I was great and that they couldn't 
even tell that I was messing up, but I felt like everyone was judging and 
staring at me for the next two weeks. ﻿
comments.author: Tamara Hocken

comments.text: I was going to comment but realized that nobody probably cared. XD﻿
comments.author: Harrison Lee

comments.text:
Once, while in the midst of some amiable bantering with my history teacher 
during class, my teacher replied to one of my remarks that I was "a harsh 
critic." The thought immediately struck me to counter with this golden pun: 
"More like a DARSH critic!" Of course, my mental brakes paralyzed me from 
making that statement, and I began to giggle like I was tripped up on 
nitrous oxide while my teacher, ever the encouraging one, said: "C'mon, say 
what you were gonna say." The strange this is, I don't know if it would 
have been more embarrassing if I had actually said it. What's worse: an 
awful attempt at wordplay or a vacant burst of laughter to compensate for 
that?﻿
comments.author: Darsh Patel

comments.text:
Until I was like... 6 or 7? I was adamant that Buzz Lightyear was calling 
to his superhero frind STARKA MAN. Yeah... my mum spent a long time 
embarrassing me with that story to prove to me that I wasn't always right.﻿

whole grade just staring at me. I cry a lot about it ﻿

comments.text:
My embarrassing story is that I was in marching band back in High School 
and I was placed in the front row with a couple f the flutes. Well we had 
just got new uniforms and for some reason my pants couldn't stay buttoned, 
so in the middle of the half time show my pants fell straight down and I 
couldn't bend down to pick them up because if I stopped we would have a 
pile up behind me and then we'd all go down like dominoes in a line so I 
finished the WHOLE song with my pants down around my ankles. That's just 
ONE of the many embarrassing moments that happen to me on a daily basis.﻿
comments.author: Faith Snyder

comments.text:
Oh no! I've been saying FACADE wrong! :O Omg.... lmfao. I thought Facade 
and Facade (interchange the pronunciations to which ever order you choose)

comments.author: Faith Snyder

comments.text:
In high school a hypnotist did an assembly at my school. He did a trick on 
the crowd to make people think their hands were stuck together and it 
worked on me. So he said "if your hands are stuck together come to the 
front to get them released". Little did I know that was a signal for all 
his already picked volunteers to go up on stage. 

So I'm sitting in front of my whole senior class realizing "oh crap I'm not 
supposed to be up here". Meanwhile he's going down the line putting people 
to sleep on command. He gets to me and it doesn't work but I thought it 
would look more stupid to sit there staring at him so I pretend to fall 
asleep. But I had gum in my mouth and kept chewing the gum and only 
realized that after the entire auditorium erupted in laughter. The worse 
part is afterwards everybody thought I was screwing with the hypnotist when 
I was really just scrambling trying to not look stupid. ﻿
comments.author: Danny Leach

comments.text:
So me and this guy were talking all day and snapchating all day. At the 
end we decided we fucked up because he has a girlfriend so the next day we 
were hanging out with a couple other people and it was soooo awkward and we 
barely talked or even looked at each other. So later I saw that he 
snapchatted me again and I was super happy because I didn't want it to be 
awkward...so I sent two snapchats back when I realized he put the snapchat 
as a story (which means all his friends can see it and it is sent to 
everyone) I was super embarrassed because I sent two after that super 
awkward day it sucks because he is a really cool guy and I enjoyed seeing 
he and now I am super nervous to see him this Monday. 


The reason I am putting this up is because I have looked up so many videos 
on how to not be embarrassed and they all show up as really social 
embarrassing things (like tripping in front of your crush) but nothing came 
up for things like this... So I hope it's nice for someone to know that I'm 
going through one of those oh god I have no idea what he is thinking 
moments. Fuck I'm so nervous I have to see him either tm or Monday!! ﻿
comments.author: sara bilankov

comments.text:

saying "Such great singing!". Then he asked if he could have the vacuumer 
and said that If I wanted, he could wait outside for it, listening to my 
singing.

I died. </3﻿

around me were also very good (cause I did most of the work) until one day

comments.author: Filiq Man

comments.text:
The first ever comment someone I didn't know ever made on one of my videos, 
just as I was finally beginning to feel more confident in my channel and 
getting excited about making more content, was simply, "Damn, no one 
watched your video." I didn't want to delete the comment and tried to tell 
myself that it was still "something," but I wouldn't wish the embarrassment 
I felt on anyone. I went from being so excited to get an e-mail that 
someone had commented, to being mortified--even to the point of considering 
taking down all of my videos (none of which, according to his standard, 
"anyone has watched," but all of which I try to be proud). --Thanks Hank, 
this is definitely one for the "favorites" list to go back to on not so 
made-of-awesome days.

**I know this is probably gonna seem like intentional self promotion to 
some... but I assure you, it is unintentional self promotion... carry on.﻿
comments.author: Amanda Lynn Scott

comments.text:
Once in my 10th grade Spanish class we were being called on by the teacher 
to individually identify what so and so word on the board was in English. 
The entire unit was about indoor appliances. I was called on and obviously 
didn't know the answer and one of my classmates whispered "sidewalk." So 
naturally I said that in response to the teacher. The entire class laughed 
for about 2-3 minutes and every time I was ever called on after that people 
whispered "sidewalk."﻿

comments.author: Hannah Schnell

comments.text:
When I was in first or second grade I went to a summer camp at the place I 
had gone to preschool. This was a camp in which there were both elementary 
school kids and preschoolers. One morning I was standing with a girl I knew 
from school who was bent on informing me of the fact that the phrase "I 
swear to God" is akin to "I promise." I, being a naïve and not very well 
socialized child, did not believe her, but later that afternoon tried it 
out anyway to sound cool. A girl of about 4 years of age happened to wander 
by at that exact moment, and, spinning on her heels, pointed a trembling 
finger at me and screamed, "SHE SWORE!" To which I, being also an idiot, 
responded, "No, I didn't - I swear to God!" Then she wailed at me for 
swearing again, and she started crying, and I started crying, and the 
counselors, who up to that point had thought of me as the sweet 
kind-hearted soul they'd known for years, didn't really know what to do. A 
decade later, I still have emotional baggage. And I have never sworn to God 
since... This has been oddly therapeutic. Thank you, Hank!﻿
comments.author: Fiona D

comments.text: Yaaas hank yaaaaas﻿
comments.author: Bri Brown

comments.text: dying at 1st comment

comments.text: hes gay
comments.author: Tucker Weinberg

comments.author: Tucker Weinberg

comments.text:
...I've blocked most of my embarrassing moments from my memory. I mean, 
obviously I've pronounced words wrongly (for years I misread "enigma" and 
thought it was pronounced, "engima"), but I never really got embarrassed at 
that. I mean, one of my earliest memories is of sounding out some word from 
a book I was reading when asking my parents for a definition, and getting 
it so horribly wrong that in the end I had to spell the word so that they'd 
know what I was trying to say XD And occasionally I still do that (I don't 
often find words I don't know in books anymore). Probably most of the 
reason I don't really get embarrassed anymore is because I've come to the 
conclusion that I have my friends, and I like my friends, and they're 
allowed to laugh at me. And I don't much care what anyone who isn't one of 
my friends thinks about me. So it becomes hard to get embarrassed about 
things, 'cause I legit don't care if people think I'm odd or not.﻿
comments.author: Lyria0chan

comments.text:

comments.text:
I was in a crowded art class that was normally pretty loud, and it was DEAD 
SILENT this day, but I had headphones on listening to a japanese rock band. 
There was a loud long beep in the song so I basically shouted at my friend 
"WOW they swear for a long time here." And... EVERYONE STARED. oh man. My 
14 year old self wanted to melt into the ground and die. XD it still makes 
me cringe sometimes. 
Second one coming to mind is getting in a fight with a friend and walking 
off... and my skirt rode up so she shouted down the hallway that she could 
see my butt (She didn't use the word butt).  ((looking back I should have 
just said' WELL GOOD' in return haha))﻿
comments.author: TatsuKitty

comments.text:
I guess I may as well participate. In second grade, I was at a performance 
of twelfth night put on by the 8th grade class. About 200 students from the 
1st - 7th grade were in the audience. In the middle of the play, I let out 
the loudest, drawn out bout of flatulence that I could imagine (at least it 
seems that way). The actors stopped, and everyone in the audience looked at 
me, so I said "excuse me" in a very timid voice. One of the leads actually 
fell off the stage laughing. That was probably the most embarrassing moment 
of my life to date, and hope not to have to top it ANY time soon.﻿
comments.author: Jesse Payton

comments.text:
I was in the school musical and I stuffed up my own name!!! I couldn't say

Everyone laughed, and to this day, my friends still call me "Lady Blah"...﻿
